DOC.HEAD: US Calls Cuba a ``Renegade Nation''
EDs: ADDS 9 grafs, State Department comment on terrorism and Cuban view; Add byline
DOC.TEXT: The State Department renewed its criticism on Monday of Cuban arms shipments to Central America and said ``it is time for Cuba to stop acting like a renegade nation.'' Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Cuba should stop sending weapons to Nicaragua's leftist government and Nicaragua should stop sending such arms on to Salvadoran rebels. She said that Cuba must begin shouldering more responsibility than before because it will soon become a member of the U.N. Security Council. ``It needs now to begin acting in a way consistent with the great responsibility it will bear in the council,'' she said. Her statement suggested a shift in emphasis about the U.S. view of who is to blame for the continuing upheaval in Central America. The administration previously had said the Soviet Union had a duty to persuade Cuba and Nicaragua to block the transfer of Soviet bloc weapons to the Salvadoran insurgency. In her remarks on Monday, Ms. Tutwiler seemed to play down Soviet responsibility for the continuing violence in Central America. But, under questioning, she said that the administration has not backed away from its previous view and that Central America continues to be a divisive issue for Moscow and Washington. The administration does not challenge Moscow's contention that it has ceased direct arms deliveries to Central America. But officials say they are convinced that some Soviet weapons arrive in Central America via third countries, especially Cuba. Monday evening, in response to a press question, the State Department said that Cuba continues to be one of six countries on a U.S. government list of countries that support international terrorism. ``Cuba continues to provide safe haven, weapons and political and financial support to a wide range of leftist and insurgent organizations that use terrorism,'' the department said. It said Cuba supports a Colombian leftist group that has attacked western economic interests. In addition, it said that the Salvadoran rebel group backed by Cuba has publicly threatened Americans assisting the Salvadoran government as ``legitimate targets of assassination.'' Also, Cuba has supported a leftist group in Chile believed responsible for several international terrorist incidents in recent years, the department said. Joining Cuba on the State Department terrorism list are Iran, Syria, Libya, South Yemen and North Korea. Cuba, in turn, regards the United States as the country most prone to international adventurism worldwide. It has cited repeated U.S.-sponsored assassination attempts against President Fidel Castro and large-scale American military involvement in Central America. Castro recently accused the United States of directly intervening in the internal affairs of the Philippines by lending air support to President Corazon Aquino during the recent coup attempt. Beyond that, Castro said that the worldwide U.S. network of military bases gives the United States the capability to intervene in virtually any region on short notice.
